Fredrik,

I'll stick my neck out first.
   I'd say same design, later copy. Possibly much
later. There are several differences. For starters,
the shape of the seppa dai. The quality of the iron is
also an important one and probably why Jim's is dated
as he has it. The sukashi on his is very gentle, yet
the iron like extra hard armor iron so the tsuba could
be considered either kyo-sukashi or katchushi.

In a case like yours, someone just needs to make a
judgement call on the iron and the workmanship of the
sukashi. 

Curran



--- Fredrik Persson <fredmans@...> wrote:

> Hi all,
> This post is mainly directed to Mr Gilbert but I
> thought that maybe if 
> someone else would like to comment that would be
> great.
> I was browsing your lovely tsuba site and have a
> question regarding the 
> last tsuba on page two of the Early Iron tsuba link.
> http://home.earthlink.net/%7Ejggilbert/oldiron2.htm
> You are writing that it's an unusual guard, does
> this mean its hard to 
> kantei? How confident are you about it being a late
> Muromachi tsuba? 
> Have you or someone else seen this type of tsuba
> before, maybe in books 
> as for reference?
> The thing is that I have a very similar tsuba,
> almost identical, and i 
> would like to have as much information about it as
> possible. Do you 
> think it may be from the same era as yours or would
> mine be a later copy?
> The measurements on my tsuba are almost the same as
> yours, mine is 
> slightly thicker.
> 8.0 cm H x 8.0 cm W x 0.4 cm T
> 
> Please take a look at it on
> http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Tsuba1.htm
> 
> Regards
> Fredrik
> 
> 
>
